Solketal formation from glycerol and acetone over hierarchical zeolites of different structure as catalysts J. Kowalska-Kus ⁎ A. Held M. Frankowski K. Nowinska Faculty of Chemistry, Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, Poland Faculty of Chemistry Adam Mickiewicz University Poznan Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Hierarchical zeolites demonstrated very excellent glycerol conversion and selectivity to the desired product (solketal) for acetalization reaction. Glycerol acetalization reaction with acetone was performed at 343K and using a 1:1 molar ratio of glycerol to acetone in the feed over hierarchical zeolites comprising pores of different diameters (MFI, BEA, and MOR). The best catalytic performance for glycerol acetalization was exhibited by hierarchical (micro-mesoporous) MFI zeolites. Glycerol conversion over MFI zeolites exceeded 80%, with almost 100% selectivity to the desired product (4-hydroxymethyl-2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolane known as solketal). A significant increase in glycerol conversion and also selectivity to solketal in the studied reaction resulted from the easier accessibility of the active sites to reagents due to the formation of mesopores by means of desilication of the microporous zeolites. Keywords Acetalization Glycerol Desilication Dealumination Hierarchical zeolites 1 Introduction Transesterification of vegetable oil and animal fats with methanol results not only in the production of biodiesel but also in the formation of a significant amount of waste glycerol phase (about 100kg for every tonne of biodiesel) which, besides glycerol, is also comprised of spent catalyst and excess methanol [1]. Considering that an increase in biodiesel production brings about an increasing surplus of glycerol, its efficient utilization is very challenging. Glycerol may be transformed into different chemicals that are intermediate for the production of consumer goods. Among others are acroleine and acrylic acid obtained by the oxydehydration process [2,3], which are polymerized to acrylates; propylene glycol from glycerol hydrogenolysis [4], applied in the pharmaceutical and food industry, and also dihydroxyacetone (produced by glycerol oxidation [5,6]), used for the production of cosmetics and medicines. One promising procedure for glycerol utilization is the reaction of glycerol with acetone or formaldehyde in the presence of acidic catalysts to produce acetals or ketals [7–9]. A practical application of solketal, a product of glycerol acetalization with acetone, has been found in a number of industrial processes [10]. It may be used in the polymer industry as a plasticizer, in pharmaceutical production as suspending agent, and additionally as a fuel additive, increasing the octane number of gasoline and reducing the emissions resulting from fuel combustion. The reaction of glycerol and acetone is a reversible process resulting in 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolane-4-methanol (solketal) and water according to Scheme 1 . Isomeric 1,3-dioxan-5-ol may also be produced [11]. Our studies are concentrated on searching for the stable, easily accessible, and active catalyst for the acetalization reaction. Traditionally, liquid inorganic acids have been applied as catalysts for the mentioned process. Owing to the problems involved with both product separation and the utilization of spent catalysts, extensive research on the applications of heterogeneous catalysts has been undertaken [12]. Among different solid acidic catalysts such as heteropolyacids [13], mesostructure silica modified in a different manner (i.e. sulfonic acid-functionalized materials) [14], acidic resins such as Amberlyst [15], and also various kinds of zeolites were tested [16–19]. So far, the best catalytic performance for glycerol acetalization exhibited Amberlyst. However, its application on a wide scale is limited due to its low thermal stability hindering the regeneration of Amberlyst by calcination after several using. Therefore, more suitable catalysts of acetalization seem to be zeolites. The highest activity in the studied reaction was found over BEA zeolite. Despite significant activity of BEA zeolite, its high price makes the process of glycerol utilization not profitable. On the other hand, acetalization of glycerol performed over MFI zeolites, due to their relatively low price, wide availability and high thermal stability, should be very attractive. The restriction that brings about lower activity of MFI catalysts for this process is related to the shape-selectivity properties associated with the relatively narrow channel size [20]. Our earlier calculation using the GaussView programme exploitation [21] indicated that the diameter of the acetalization products is situated in the range of 0.43–0.51nm, which could result in diffusion limitation. The previous studies have therefore become an inspiration to improve the activity of zeolites for glycerol acetalization by limitation of diffusion restriction. This goal has been attained by application of hierarchical (micro-mesoporous) MFI, BEA and MOR zeolites as heterogeneous catalysts used for glycerol with acetone acetalization. For this purpose, in the present paper, zeolites of MFI structure (pore diameter 0.51–0.55nm) as well as BEA, and MOR, characterized with higher channel diameters (0.61–0.67nm and 0.67–0.70nm, respectively [20]), were prepared by desilication procedure, which is relatively cheap and easy modification. It was expected that the application of micro-mesoporous zeolites as catalysts for glycerol acetalization should demonstrate excellent glycerol conversion and selectivity to the desired product. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials H-MFI (Süd Chemie, Si/Al=12 and Alsi Penta, Si/Al=27; denoted as MFI-1-P, MFI-2-P, respectively), H-Mordenite (PQ Corporation, Si/Al=17; designed as MOR-P) and H-Beta (Sigma Aldrich, Si/Al=12; denoted as BEA-P) were used as raw materials for alkaline and subsequent acidic treatment. 2.2 Catalyst modification 2.2.1 Alkaline treatment All the commercial zeolites were alkali-treated using the following procedure. 5.0g of zeolite was added to a 0.2M (150ml) aqueous NaOH solution and stirred at 353K for 2h. Afterwards, the slurry was cooled, filtered, and then washed with distilled water until the pH of the filtration solution decreased to 7. After drying at 363K for 12h, the alkali-treated zeolite was ion exchanged with 0.5M NH4NO3 aqueous solution by stirring at 308K for 24h, followed by filtering and rinsing with distilled water to remove sodium ions. After drying at 363K for 12h, the ammonium form of zeolite was subsequently calcined in static air at 823K for 3h to form the H-form, denoted as MFI-number-AT, MOR-AT and BEA-AT, respectively. 2.2.2 Acidic treatment Some of the alkaline treated samples were used for further acid treatment with aqueous solutions of nitric or citric acids. The procedure of the acid treatment was as follows. One part of zeolite was put into 0.5M nitrate acid (NA) solution and the second one was placed in 0.5M citric acid (CA) solution. The resulting mixtures were kept at 353K for 3h with stirring. The slurry was then cooled down, washed and dried at 363K for 12h and the resulting samples were designated as MFI-number-NA, MOR-NA, BEA-NA and MFI-number-CA, MOR-CA, BEA-CA, respectively. Finally, all the treated samples were calcined at 823K for 3h. 2.3 Characterization 2.3.1 XRD X-ray diffraction measurements were carried out on a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer using CuKα radiation in order to confirm the structural correctness of the prepared samples. Lowering of the crystallinity of alkali treated catalysts with comparison to the parent ones was determined according to the method described in ref. [20,22,23]. The relative crystallinity was calculated according to Eq. (1). (1) α=αo ×I/Io where we assume αo as equal to 100, I and Io are the areas of the reflexes characteristic of parent and modified zeolites, respectively. The I and Io values response to the sum of the areas of the most intense peaks at 2 Theta: 23.1°, 23.3°,23.7°, 23.9°, 24.4° for MFI zeolite; 25.8°, 26.5°, 27.8° for MOR and 22.5° for BEA zeolite. 2.3.2 Elemental analysis Approximately 50mg of the sample was weighed, placed in a Teflon bottle and 8ml of supra pure nitric acid (Sigma-Aldrich) was added. Then Teflon bottles were placed on the heating plate with magnetic stirring for 30min. After this time 2ml of hydrofluoric acid (Sigma-Aldrich) was added and placed again on the heating plate with magnetic stirring until dissolution (around 30min). After cooling, the samples were placed in polyethylene volumetric flasks and filled up to 100ml with deionised water. The content of aluminium and silicon were determined by atomic absorption spectrometry with acetylene-nitrous oxide flame atomisation (F-AAS) using the 3D double-beam Shimadzu AA7000 analytical technique (Shimadzu), equipped with an ASC-7000 autosampler (Shimadzu). The hollow cathode lamps (HCL) employed were made by Photron. 2.3.3 BET N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were recorded on a Quantachrome Nova1000e analyzer at 77K. The total surface area was calculated according to the BET equation. The micropore and mesopore volume, and the external surface area were evaluated by the t-plot method. Pore size was reported as the average pore diameter. Before measurements the samples were preheated at 573K for 4h in vacuum. 2.3.4 FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine The FT-IR spectroscopic self-supporting wafer technique on a Bruker-Vector 22 spectrometer was used to determine the acidic properties of the parent and modified zeolites. The wafers (20mg/cm2) were prepared from powdered zeolites. Initially, the samples were heated in vacuum at 673K for 2h. The samples were then cooled to the room temperature (RT) after which the pyridine was adsorbed with following evacuation at 373K to remove physically adsorbed pyridine. The desorption temperature points were 373K, 473K, 573K, and 673K. The spectrum was recorded after desorption in vacuum at a related temperature for 30min. The number of acidic centers was calculated with Eq. (2) [21,24]: (2) n T = A L C d ε L m + A B C d ε B m nT – total number of acidic sites expressed as micromoles of pyridine per 1g of catalyst, AL and AB – integrated absorbance of IR bands related to Lewis and Brønsted sites, Cd – cross section of wafer in cm2 and m – mass in g of pressed pellet, and εL and εB molar absorption coefficients for Lewis and Brønsted acid sites equal to 1.5 and 1.8 [μmol−1 cm], respectively. 2.4 Catalytic activity measurement The activity of the parent and modified zeolites was tested for the acetalization reaction of glycerol with acetone. The reagents used in the experiments, glycerol (99.5% purity) and acetone (99% purity), were purchased from Chempur. All the experiments were conducted at a temperature of 343K in closed glass vials of 4cm3 capacity, under vigorous stirring (400rpm) in a multiple-well parallel reaction block in the presence of catalyst in the amount of 1% related to glycerol. A 1: 1 molar ratio of glycerol to acetone was used in the feed. Catalysts were pre-activated in air at 623K for 2h followed by cooling down in a desiccator before the catalytic run. Liquid products were analysed by GC, using a VARIAN CP-3800 chromatograph equipped with an FID detector with a VF-5ms column. Besides a predominant product, a 5-membered ring ketal 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolane-4-methanol (solketal) and unreacted glycerol and acetone, only a 6-membered ring ketal 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolane-5-ol, a by-product, was identified by the Varian 4000 GC–MS apparatus. The catalytic activity, reported as glycerol conversion (denoted as G C), selectivity to products: solketal (denoted as S S) and isomer (denoted as S I), solketal yield (denoted as Y S), was calculated on the basis of the equations presented in [25]. Conversion of glycerol (%) (3) C = m o l o f g l y c e r o l c o n v e r t e d i n i t i a l m o l o f g l y c e r o l × 100 where mol of glycerol converted=initialmol of glycerol − final mol of glycerol Selectivity to solketal or isomer (%) (4) S = m o l o f X f o r m e d m o l o f g l y c e r o l c o n v e r t e d × 100 where X=solketal or isomer Yield of solketal (%) (5) Y = S × C 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD The XRD patterns of parent and modified zeolites of MFI structure are presented in Fig. 1 and BEA and MOR structures are demonstrated in Fig. 2 . The patterns show that the proper structure of the zeolites has been preserved in the samples after the alkaline treatment and after the ionic exchange with aqueous solutions of NH4NO3. No additional phase was noted in the modified samples. However, a small decrease in the intensities of the characteristic reflexes was observed, which suggests a lowering of the crystallinity. The related crystallinity of the modified samples with reference to the initial materials is listed in Table 1 . These results prove that alkali treatment induces some lowering in the crystallinity. A decrease in crystallinity was visible for both MFI zeolites, at a similar level (about 30% of the initial value). A similar reduction of crystallinity was noted for MOR (30% of the initial value), while the crystallinity of BEA zeolite was practically unchanged (2% of the initial value). The following treatment of desilicated samples with HNO3 or C6H8O7 solutions in the next step of catalyst modification was motivated by the literature suggestions [26], indicating the possible occlusion of aluminum and hindrance of mesopores opening in alkaline treated zeolites. The data showed that acidic treatment does not influence the crystalline structure of the modified zeolites significantly, however, it results in an increase in the Si/Al ratio (Table 1). Only the treatment of desilicated BEA zeolite with nitric acid leads to some lowering in the crystallinity up to 81%. This may be due to the partial extraction of framework aluminum from BEA zeolite, considering that BEA zeolite is relatively easy to dealuminate [20]. A similar alteration of the crystallinity of BEA zeolite modified by means of desilication with following treatment with nitric acid solution was reported by Wang et al. [27]. 3.1.2 Si/Al ratio The alkali treatment of zeolite should lead to a preferential desilication, which would then be reflected in the changing of Si/Al ratio. The Si/Al ratios of the parent and modified zeolites are presented in Table 1. The Si/Al ratio of all alkaline treated zeolites obtained via the F-AAS analysis was found to be lower than that of the parent catalysts. The presented results indicate that the higher Si/Al in applied MFI zeolites, the higher the degree of desilication was observed. According to literature [26,28,29], desilication of zeolite depends significantly on the Si/Al ratio of the initial material as well as on the applied conditions. A high concentration of framework aluminum (low Si/Al ratio) results in restriction of the silicon removal and in limitation of mesoporosity development. This is in accordance with the lower degree of desilication in the MFI zeolite of Si/Al equal to 12, when compared to the sample with Si/Al equal to 27 (Table 1). On the other hand, the relatively high mesoporosity achieved in our experiment over MFI-1-AT may result from long duration of the treatment (2h) at a relatively high temperature 353K. The influence of zeolite structure on the desilication process has been indicated in the literature [30]. According to the results presented in Table 1 silicon removal as an effect of alkaline treatment results in a decrease in the Si/Al ratio in the following way: MFI(27)>MOR(17)∼MFI(12)>BEA(12). Subsequent treatment with acids (HNO3 or C6H8O7) brings about an increase in the Si/Al ratio as a result of aluminum removal. Susceptibility to dealumination is especially visible for MOR and BEA zeolites. It has been shown by Groen et al. [31] and also by Tian et al. [32] that resistance of BEA zeolite to dealumination is lower when compared to MFI zeolites. 3.1.3 Textural properties The influence of the alkali treatment on the porosity of the applied zeolites was studied by the N2 adsorption–desorption procedure at 77K and the results are listed in Table 1. Alkaline treatment of the zeolites with NaOH solution and the following ionic exchange with aqueous solution of NH4NO3 leads to spectacular mesopore formation. However, the enlargement of the surface area and the mesoporosity depends on the structure of the initial samples. MFI zeolites with a different Si/Al ratio show a similar increase in surface area (in the range of 20–25% of the initial values), while the surface area of BEA zeolite increases by 10% and changes only slightly for MOR (3% of the initial value). Desilication also results in an increase of the surface of mesopores. The contribution of mesopores in total surface area increased from approximately 10% for initial zeolites of MFI structure to about 50% for modified ones, while for the BEA zeolite and MOR the contribution of mesopores increased from 32% to about 50% and from 19% to about 34%, respectively. The following treatment with HNO3 or C6H8O7 acid solutions influenced the textural parameters only slightly (Figs. 1 and 2). Even though, no significant changes in the modified zeolite texture were recorded, the Si/Al ratio increased (Table 1) and Brønsted as well as Lewis acidity decreased (Table 2 ) after acidic treatment, confirming partial aluminum removal. As shown in Fig. 3 , the isotherms of both MFI zeolites showed typical Langmuir Type-I adsorption patterns prior to alkali-treatment. After alkaline treatment, all the isotherms exhibited distinct hysteresis loops indicating Type-IV behavior as a result of mesopores formation from the desilication process. This is in agreement with the observed increase in pore volume as well as in enlargement of the contribution of mesopores surface in the total surface area (Table 1). A similar alteration in zeolite texture was described in the literature as a result of the desilication procedure [26]. Although the isotherms of parent BEA and MOR (Fig. 4 ) show some hysteresis due to the presence of mesopores, the hysteresis loop increases visibly as a result of the desilication process. The average pore diameter of modified samples was shifted towards higher values, indicating the formation of macropores in the modified samples. A similarly high pore diameter was reported in the literature [20,29]. 3.1.4 Acidic properties The acidity of the parent and modified zeolites was estimated on the basis of the FT-IR spectra of adsorbed pyridine after desorption at a temperature in the range of 373–673K. Table 2 summarizes the acidic properties of all applied zeolites. Desilication of MFI and also MOR and BEA zeolites with following ionic exchange with NH4NO3 resulted in the increase of both total acidity estimated at 373K (Figs. 5 and 6 ) as well as strong acidity measured after the evacuation of pyridine at 673K (Table 2). Both Brønsted acidity and Lewis acidity were responsible for the increase in total acidity in MFI zeolites. The high acidity after the desilication process indicates that aluminum is still in tetrahedral coordination. On the other hand, the lower Brønsted acidity and higher Lewis acidity observed on desilicated MOR and BEA zeolites may evidence that the dealumination process occurs with desilication (Tables 1 and 2). When the desilicated samples were treated with aqueous solutions of HNO3 or C6H8O7, the Lewis acidity was clearly lower in comparison with the samples exchanged with NH4NO3. This suggests that the treatment of desilicated zeolites with acidic solutions results in dissolution of aluminum debris, as suggested in the literature [26]. This is in accordance with alteration in the Si/Al ratio (Table 1). 3.2 Catalytic activity for glycerol acetalization Acetalization of glycerol with acetone to obtain solketal was tested over parent zeolites of MFI, MOR and BEA structures and also on the materials subjected to desilication with following ionic exchange with NH4NO3 solution and subsequent acidic treatment. Protonic forms of commercial zeolites displayed very different activity for glycerol acetalization depending on their pore arrangement. The initial MOR and BEA zeolites characterized by a relatively large pore opening (diameter of about 0.67nm) and higher accessibility to active sites for the reactants show glycerol conversion in the range of 67–72% (Figs. 9 and 10 ). The desilication process of MOR and BEA zeolites with generation of mesoporosity resulted in some increase in glycerol conversion up to 81%. The following treatment with citric acid alters the glycerol conversion slightly, while treatment with nitric acid results in a reduction of glycerol conversion. A similar tendency in the lowering of glycerol conversion over all zeolites treated with nitric acid, compared to values obtained after citric acid modification, may arise from a significant decrease in acidic sites resulting from partial dealumination (Tables 1 and 2). The activity of the parent zeolites of MFI structure, characterized by a different Si/Al ratio equal to 12 and 27, was definitely lower (18% and 37%, respectively), because of the diffusion limitation (Figs. 7 and 8). According to the literature [33] the Si/Al ratio affects the desilication process and a value in the range of 25–50 has been indicated as optimal. The desilication process resulted in an increase in glycerol conversion. The glycerol conversion over MFI-1-AT reached 30%, whereas on the MFI-2-AT it increased up to 80% (Figs. 7 and 8). The following treatment with citric acid resulted in a significant increase in glycerol conversion up to 82% and 85%, respectively. It seems that aluminum debris do not block the mesopores for small nitrogen molecules (N2 applied for porosity estimation), while they are not quite available for reagents. Therefore, the removal of aluminum debris results in a significant increase in glycerol conversion. The desilication of zeolites also resulted in an increase in selectivity to solketal, which achieved nearly 100%. Solketal, the main product of the acetalization reaction, is kinetically favoured, while the isomer 1,3 dioxane is thermodynamically more stable. Longer contact time with catalytically active sites may result in isomeric molecule formation (bringing about the selectivity to 1,3 dioxane up to 25–27 on MFI-1P and MFI-2P – Figs. 7 and 8), therefore, faster diffusion due to the presence of mesopores seems to be responsible for limitation of its production up to 3%. The obtained data confirm that an almost 80% yield of solketal, as the predominant product, was obtained in the acetalization reaction. Interestingly, high glycerol conversion (80% or more) and near 100% selectivity to solketal was achieved for the stoichiometric acetone to glycerol ratio (acetone: glycerol=1:1). Considering that the acetalization of glycerol with acetone is a reversible reaction, a higher acetone to glycerol molar ratio shifts the reaction towards the products. The best solketal yield reported in the literature was achieved for an acetone to glycerol ratio equal to 4:1 [34]. The obtained results indicate that the desilication of zeolites can create highly efficient catalysts for glycerol acetalization. 4 Conclusions Glycerol acetalization reaction with acetone performed for the very first time over large pores, hierarchical zeolites (MFI, BEA and MOR) as catalysts resulted in a significant increase in glycerol conversion, even exceeding 80%. As a result of a dramatic shortening of diffusion path length, selectivity to solketal reached almost 100%. The most substantial increase in activity for the acetalization reaction was recorded over hierarchical MFI zeolites which could enable the utilization of commonly used MFI zeolites in an industrially relevant process of glycerol transformation. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol acetalization reaction with acetone was performed at 343K and using a 1:1 molar ratio of glycerol to acetone in the feed over hierarchical zeolites comprising pores of different diameters (MFI, BEA, and MOR). The best catalytic performance for glycerol acetalization was exhibited by hierarchical (micro-mesoporous) MFI zeolites. Glycerol conversion over MFI zeolites exceeded 80%, with almost 100% selectivity to the desired product (4-hydroxymethyl-2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolane known as solketal). A significant increase in glycerol conversion and also selectivity to solketal in the studied reaction resulted from the easier accessibility of the active sites to reagents due to the formation of mesopores by means of desilication of the microporous zeolites.
coredata.dc:title: Solketal formation from glycerol and acetone over hierarchical zeolites of different structure as catalysts
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
